newsitem.title: INDIA: Bad roads threaten Indian car industry - report.
newsitem.headline: Bad roads threaten Indian car industry - report.

text.p: Inadequate infrastructure facilities, mainly a poor road network, could slow the growth of India's car industry, officials said on Tuesday.

"Lack of infrastructure, particularly roads, will affect the automobile industry," Brijmohan Lall, president of the All India Association of Automobile Manufacturers (AIAM), told a business conference.
The AIAM said in a report released on Monday that the poorly maintained road network was likely to put a brake on the booming domestic automobile industry.
India began opening its domestic car industry to foreign investors as a part of an economic liberalisation programme launched in 1991.
Indian car sales have risen by 25 to 27 percent in the past two years, officials said.
The report said India's 2.2 million km (13 million miles) of roads were inadequate to accommodate the growing numbers of vehicles.
"With a total vehicle population of about 31 million units, the infrastructure is not adequate enough," Surface Transport Minister T.G. Venkatraman said.
The car makers must adopt stringent emission norms and improved technology to produce vehicles which pollute less, he said.

"India with its vast resources of Compressed Natural Gas (CNG) and Liquid Petroleum Gas (LPG) has a capability to operate large number of vehicles on these alternate fuels," Venkatraman said, adding this would reduce pollution.
He said government investment in public transport had dwindled in the last five years, leading to an increase in the number of vehicles.
"The government is making all-out efforts to improve roads," Venkatraman said.
He said the financing requirements of building additional roads was enormous and this would require the coming together of the government and the private sector.
